content: One more tip: If the account is IMAP, I suggest having the filter COPY the messages to the Local Folder archive folder. Then, after a successful copy, change the filter to 'delete' and run again. Doing the archive process this way ensures the messages are free from the account and the space used within the account is freed. Otherwise, if you just MOVE the messages, you are not achieving the objective of creating a separate folder from the account. Be sure to do backups, as the archives are on your PC.
creator: davidsk

content: I do not understand your problem. It needs more detail. I successfully test plus addressing and it works as intended. Part of your issue may be that you have a filter that strips the message. My understanding is that this is a feature of gmail. If you set up plus addresses as aliases in gmail, you can send and receive it. So, a message from a person using 'emailaddress+joe@gmail.com, can be readily replied to as emailaddress+joe@gmail.com. What am I not understanding here? I do not see a bug here. the plus addressing was defined by an email provider and that email provider administers these aliases, just as other email providers administer their aliases.

content:
This is how to set fonts for viewing and writing:

- go to TB menu > Settings > General > Language & Fonts > Fonts > click 'Advanced' button

- at the top, set 'Fonts for:' to Latin if it isn't already

- change Proportional and Monospace fonts/sizes to your liking

- set Minimum font size to 14

- at the top, change set 'Fonts for:' to Other Writing Systems

- repeat the process of changing fonts/sizes

- at the bottom, make sure 'Allow messages to use other fonts' is disabled if desired > OK > close the popup

content: Actually, when one combines HTML font options, the choices get bigger. Persons who just use HTML fonts are usually more confused because thunderbird attempts to minimize impact on recipients, letting them pick their chosen fonts. If you use 'variable font' in HTML, and medium size, NO FONT specs are sent. This is considered good by many, as the recipient isn't dependent on the sender's font. This is one of those issues where we could discuss over beer and peanuts for hours, achieving little more than headaches and calories. :) take care.

content: 4.3 GB is very big for an Inbox folder. Inbox folders are not meant to store decades of message traffic and it's better to store messages you want (or you need) to keep in Archive folders. You may also create thematic folders in the Local Folders for long time storing. You may try to rebuild the Global Database https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/rebuilding-global-database Rebuilding the global-messages-db.sqlite file after restart of Thunderbird might take several hours depending on the number of messages in your Thunderbird profile.
creator: Mapenzi

content: 1. Rebuilding the Global Database did not hjælp. 2. How I can Archive bedst my messeges ?
creator: ak8

content:
You may archive messages using Thunderbird's "archive" feature, following explanations in this article https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/archived-messages

Instead of using the archive feature many Thunderbird users create thematic folders in Local Folders to store messages from their Inbox, such as Banking, Invoices, Family, Taxes, ... etc

Remember: after archiving your Inbox messages, whatever the method you'll use, you have to "compact" the Inbox folder: otherwise the Inbox folder will never get smaller https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders

content:
ak8 said
hej If I have this. What should I du ?

Do yo say that you have the problem described in bug 1979580 ? You may wait and live with until the search function will be improved? But if slow search concerns only this big 4.3 GB Inbox folder, you should begin to down-size it: delete every unimportant message and archive the other messages. Begin with the oldest messages and from time to time compact the Inbox folder to diminish the size of the Inbox file in the profile where the Inbox messages are stored. When using the maildir (mailbox) format for message storage, the Inbox folders should be kept as small as possible.

content: I presume the account is IMAP. Yes, if you delete locally, the messages are deleted from server. The solution is to copy old messages to Local Folders and then to delete from server. I just responded yesterday to a user with the same problem, but differently worded. I think if you read that thread you will see exactly what to do. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1564841 Any questions, just reply back to this thread. Basically, the steps are - use a filter to identify the old messages and copy them to local folders - repeat the filter, modified from copy to delete, and run filter again to remove from server.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hi,maakhenk

The problem often lies not in your phone settings, but in how folders are registered on the mail server (IMAP). Even if you see them on your laptop, they may not be subscribed for syncing with other devices. Here are the basic steps to fix this: Check folder subscriptions (IMAP) If you're using Outlook on a laptop, new folders may be created locally but not subscribed for IMAP syncing: Right-click your email account (or Inbox) in your desktop version of Outlook. Select IMAP Folders... Click the Query button to refresh the list. Find the new folders in the list, select them, and click Subscribe. Click OK and wait for syncing to complete. Mobile App Features Depending on your app, folders may simply be hidden by the interface: Outlook Mobile: Click your profile icon in the upper left corner. If there's no expand arrow next to your Inbox, try clicking the folder icon at the bottom of the menu or adding the folder to Favorites on your computer—this will ensure it appears in the mobile app. Apple Mail (iPhone): Sometimes folders don't open when you click their name. Try clicking the small blue arrow (>) to the right of the parent folder name. Gmail (Android): Make sure global sync is enabled in your account settings (Settings > Account > Use Gmail sync). Resetting an account on your phone If folders are subscribed and visible in the web interface (for example, in a browser), but not on your phone, try forcing a connection refresh: In the Outlook app on your phone, go to Settings, select your account, and click Reset Account. If that doesn't work, remove the account from your phone and re-add it. This will force the app to redownload all the folder structures from the server. What email app do you use on your phone (Outlook, Apple Mail, Gmail) and what type of email do you have (Gmail, Outlook.com, corporate email)? This will help us provide more precise instructions.

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask! Best regards,Henry.M
creator: Miran.H
